awd_titl_txt: Designing light-matter hybrid states for high-performance organic (opto)electronics
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Description: Interactions between organic molecules and light may enable formation of a hybrid light-matter state (polariton). Such state has fascinating optical and electronic properties which are of interest both from the fundamental physics and from the applications perspective. The applications of polaritons include lasers, sensors, devices enabling optical communications and information processing, and many others. In this project, properties of polaritons are explored using a combination of experimental and computational approaches with the goal of designing next-generation organic optoelectronic materials and device architectures that utilize enhanced light emission and/or conductivity enabled by polaritons. The project integrates fundamental physics with materials design and device technologies, thus providing unique educational resources and infrastructure for graduate and undergraduate students, including those from underrepresented groups, involved in this project. The investigators develop educational materials based on the results of the project and related concepts and participate in a broad variety of outreach activities ranging between lab-based demonstrations for various audiences and participation in university-wide and department-wide outreach initiatives.

Technical Description: Organic (opto)electronic materials are of interest due to their low cost and tunable properties appropriate a broad range of applications has been demonstrated. One of the areas that has seen a dramatic progress is the applications relying on strong exciton-photon coupling in organic microcavities. In spite of considerable amount of theoretical and experimental work on strong exciton-photon coupling in organic materials, there is still a number of unresolved fundamental issues pertaining to the nature and properties of hybrid light-matter (polariton) states. Resolving some of these issues and providing experimental validation for some of the recent theoretical predictions, exemplified by that of a dark polariton (a hybrid state with unique photophysical characteristics), is the goal of the present research. In particular, a systematic investigation of photophysics of hybrid light-matter states and their ability to enhance charge transport in model organic semiconductors, chosen to be solution-processable functionalized acene and anthradithiophene derivatives, is carried out. For this, various modalities of optical and photoluminescence spectroscopy are combined with measurements of charge carrier dynamics and with numerical simulations. The ultimate goal of the research is to establish the nature and properties of hybrid light-matter states in microcavities and on plasmonic nanostructured substrates and to quantify the potential of such states to enhance coherent charge transport in organic crystalline materials. More specifically, the research team seeks to establish how the properties of polaritons evolve depending on the nature of excitonic states in the organic semiconductor, molecular packing and disorder, and to lay foundations for enhancing charge carrier mobility and photocurrent in high-performance organic semiconductors via coherent hybrid states.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Organic (opto)electronic materials are of interest due to their low cost and tunable properties; a broad range of their applications, from photovoltaics to three-dimensional (3D) displays, have been demonstrated. Over the past decade, remarkable enhancement in performance of organic devices has been achieved. For example, power conversion efficiencies of over 19% have been demonstrated in organic solar cells. This progress was largely enabled by the better understanding of underlying physical mechanisms that guided design of improved materials. Nevertheless, fundamental limits in performance of organic devices have not yet been achieved and therefore innovative solutions that would lead to further improvements are in demand. A promising direction is to utilize properties of light-matter hybrid states (polaritons) which form when molecular materials are placed in resonant structures such as microcavities and strong exciton-photon coupling conditions are met.  

In spite of considerable amount of work on strong exciton-photon coupling in organic materials, there is still a number of unresolved fundamental issues pertaining to the nature and properties of polaritons and how they could boost the performance of organic devices. This project has contributed to resolving some of these issues via systematic studies of polaritons in model organic semiconductor systems based on functionalized acene and anthradithiophene (ADT) derivatives as well as laid foundations for novel organic device architectures that incorporate metamaterials with engineered optical properties. The choice of the model organic materials was dictated by their high performance in organic devices relying on charge carrier mobility (such as thin-film transistors) and, additionally, by their ability to support singlet fission, which is a process that can convert a photon into two charge carrier pairs and thus enhance power conversion efficiency in solar cells.  

The project resulted so far in 6 published research articles (1 letter, 1 feature article, 3 invited), 4 full-size conference proceeding papers, 7 national (MRS, SPIE, CLEO, Ultrafast Phenomena, APS) (2 invited) and 2 regional (1 invited) meeting presentations, 6 invited seminars, and 2 articles that are currently in preparation for submission.

Intellectual Merit

We systematically investigated photophysics of hybrid light-matter states in benchmark organic semiconductors - functionalized pentacene, tetracene, and ADT derivatives - and explored integration of organic materials into devices utilizing various types of photonic structures: microcavities, nanostructured plasmonic substrates, and hyperbolic metamaterials (HMMs). First, we established how molecular packing in model organic crystals (diF R-ADT, where molecular packing is adjusted using side groups R) determines singlet fission efficiency and photoconductivity, both properties important for optoelectronic devices. Next, we placed various organic films in microcavities and demonstrated strong coupling between molecular excitons and cavity photons in all-metal and metal/distributed Bragg mirror cavities. We revealed that cavity photon preferentially couples to disordered populations in mixed-phase (amorphous/crystalline) and crystalline films, regardless of the cavity structure. This observation is important for organic devices, since coherent polariton states created in the defect-rich areas (which represent a bottleneck for organic devices that require crystalline ordering for the best performance) may relax the requirement for the crystalline order and simplify device fabrication. Next, we demonstrated strong coupling between molecular excitons and plasmons in metal nanohole arrays and HMMs. This work provides the basis for using such structures in strongly coupled organic devices utilizing planar geometries such as (photo)transistors, without the need for integration with microcavity structures.  Finally, we incorporated transistor structures into resonant microcavities. In phototransistors where the organic layer was strongly coupled to the cavity, a factor of 2-4 enhancement in photosensitivity was observed depending on the cavity detuning and wavelength of operation.  

Broader impact  

Results of the project promote understanding of fundamental physics of light-matter interactions in organic materials which is important for applications ranging between photovoltaics and polariton lasers.The PI has actively involved undergraduates, as well as female and minority students, in research. The PI's group has performed educational demonstrations for high- and middle-school students at various events. We leveraged the project to establish a state-of-the-art ultrafast laser center funded by NSF-MRI award (DMR-1920368) to OSU team which includes the PI. The team involves five faculty members from OSU Physics (2), Chemistry (1), and EECS (2) and four graduate student superusers (two are from the PI's group). The project enabled important calibrations of the experimental setups and superuser training.  The facility, key capabilities of which (ultrafast pump-probe and fluorescence microscopy in a cryomagnet) have leveraged the project, has been advertised to a broad base of users, as it is now available to researchers nation-wide as a shared facility.

The grant has supported and/or enabled research training for a EECS postdoctoral researcher (minority), 7 physics (2 female, 1 minority) and 3 EECS graduate students, and 7 physics undergraduate students (1 female).  The PI presented an invited lecture at the NSF ADVANCE-funded 50/50 mentoring series at the U Mass Lowell which is a public event that celebrates women's role in basic science and research.

  • Polariton formation in organic microcavities. Molecules (such as anthradithiophene derivatives pictured) are placed between two mirrors. Interactions between molecules and cavity photon lead to formation of hybrid light-matter states (polaritons) which are probed via angle-dependent reflectance.
    Dr. J. Van Schenck
    Copyrighted
    Oksana Ostroverkhova
    Strong coupling in organic semiconductor microcavities
  • Left: Cavity photon preferentially couples to defect-rich regions in functionalized pentacene films (red circles). In crystalline films, such regions are predominant at grain boundaries and are characterized by 40 meV lower exciton energies than those of the dominant molecular population (right).
    Dr. O. Ostroverkhova
    Copyrighted
    Oksana Ostroverkhova
    Selective strong coupling in functionalized pentacene microcavities
  • Molecular packing in functionalized anthradithiophene crystals determines preferential excitation relaxation towards formation of delocalized Frenkel exciton, entangled triplet pair (singlet fission), or self-trapped exciton (excimer).
    Dr. J. Van Schenck
    Copyrighted
    Oksana Ostroverkhova
    Molecular packing-dependent relaxation pathways.
  • Strong coupling observed in organic dye-doped polymer film placed on a hyperbolic metamaterial (HMM) substrate formed by ~10 nm thick alternating layers of Ag and ITO. Strong coupling to HMMs in this geometry is attractive for utilizing polaritons in planar devices such as transistors.

    Copyrighted

    Strong coupling in organic film on hyperbolic metamaterial
